channel.title: Nature Communications
channel.description:
Nature Communications is an open access, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, health, physical, chemical and Earth sciences. Papers published by the journal aim to represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

We are committed to providing an efficient service for both authors and readers. Our team of independent editors make rapid and fair publication decisions. Prompt dissemination of accepted papers to a wide readership and beyond is achieved through a programme of continuous online publication.

item.title: Electrodeposition of magnetic nanonetworks featuring triangular motifs and parallel ridges on a macroscopic scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65589-z

Self-organized growth often suffers from a lack of long-range order in preparing large-area nanostructures. Here, the authors develop a direct electrochemical growth technique for preparing ordered magnetic networks without the use of templates.
item.dc:title: Electrodeposition of magnetic nanonetworks featuring triangular motifs and parallel ridges on a macroscopic scale
item.dc:creator: Fei Chen
Junkang Shan
Xi Wang
Jingning Li
Fei Jia
Fan Wang
Zihao Yang
Kai Liu
Ru-Wen Peng
Mu Wang

item.title: Hyperconnected amorphous oxide networks under compression
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64843-8

Densified amorphous Al2O3 under irreversible densification undergoes of enhanced network entanglement, reaching hyperconnectivity. The enhanced network connectivity at lower pressure may promote the mechanical softening of glasses under stress.
item.dc:title: Hyperconnected amorphous oxide networks under compression
item.dc:creator: Sung Keun Lee
Elias El Ghazaoui
Jin Jung Kweon
Seoyoung Lee
Jae-Hyeon Parq

item.title: Balancing mechanical-thermal-electrical properties in cellulose ionogels via crystallization-induced molecular assembly
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64966-y

Cellulose-based ionogels are promising for flexible electronics though it is challenging to balance mechanical, ionic, and thermal properties. Here the authors use a crystallization induced molecular assembly method, affording an ionogel balancing these properties for flexible electronics.
item.dc:title: Balancing mechanical-thermal-electrical properties in cellulose ionogels via crystallization-induced molecular assembly
item.dc:creator: Xiaona Li
Zhihan Tong
Yuxuan Qiu
Zihao Zheng
Suqing Zeng
Dawei Zhao
Haipeng Yu

item.title: Cascaded nonlinear down-conversion in poling-free lithium niobate nanophotonic waveguides
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64912-y

Cascaded nonlinear optics has long enabled advances in short-wavelength generation, but equivalent approaches for long wavelengths remain underdeveloped. Here, the authors demonstrate a chip-based lithium niobate platform that delivers tunable mid-infrared light, opening new possibilities for sensing, spectroscopy, and communications.
item.dc:title: Cascaded nonlinear down-conversion in poling-free lithium niobate nanophotonic waveguides
item.dc:creator: Congliao Yan
Xuan Mao
Song Zhu
Fakun Wang
Hui Ma
Shi Fang
Jianbo Yu
Jieyuan Cui
Ming Tian

Qi Jie Wang

item.title: Film surface assemblies from chemically distinct block copolymer micelles
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65278-x

Block copolymer self-assembly enables complex nanostructures including spherical micelles, continuous cubic gyroids and Frank-Kasper phases. Here, the authors show how film surface self-assemblies of binary and ternary block copolymer micelle alloys pave a path to controlled multicomponent assemblies.
item.dc:title: Film surface assemblies from chemically distinct block copolymer micelles
item.dc:creator: Lieihn Tsaur
Luis A. Nieves-Rosado
B. P. Prajwal
Qi Zhang
Yuk Mun Li
Fernando A. Escobedo
Ulrich B. Wiesner

item.title: Boosting the brightness of aggregation-caused quenching chromophore-based covalent organic frameworks via energy level matching strategy
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64952-4

As a result of aggregation-caused quenching (ACQ), many fluorophores show only weak emission when incorporated into covalent organic frameworks. Here, the authors report the development of emissive COFs from ACQ chromophores by an energy level matching strategy.
item.dc:title: Boosting the brightness of aggregation-caused quenching chromophore-based covalent organic frameworks via energy level matching strategy
item.dc:creator: Liang Zhang
Weihang Geng
